policy_name: "All inclusive" Feed-in Tariff for small renewable energy power plants Italy (2008)
policy_title: "All inclusive" Feed-in Tariff for small renewable energy power plants
policy_instrument: Feed-in tariffs or premiums, Green certificates
policy_description:
The Decree of 11 April 2008 lays down the criteria to stimulate the production of electricity from solar thermodynamic plants, including the hybrid ones, connected to the electricity grid, built in Italy. Plants must be equipped with thermal accumulation systems. On top of the selling price, net electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 can obtain a feed-in premium for 25 years. Up to 2012 the bonus varies from EUR 0.22 to EUR 0.28 / kWh depending on the level of integration of the plants. In case of hybrid plants, the feed-in tariff decreases depending on the ratio between the amount of energy not produced by a solar energy source and the amount produced by a solar energy source. The maximum cumulative power of all solar thermodynamic plants eligible for the incentives corresponds to 1.5 million m2 of cumulative surface. The national objective of total power to be installed by 2016 corresponds to 2 million m2 of cumulative surface. For the 2013-2014 period such bonus values will be reduced by 2% a year; from 2014 onward special Ministerial Decree will define further cuts.

who_is_impacted: The policy impacts companies that are involved in the production of electricity from solar thermodynamic plants, including hybrid ones, in Italy. These companies must have plants equipped with thermal accumulation systems and connected to the electricity grid. The policy particularly affects those companies that commissioned thermodynamic solar plants after 18 July 2008, as they can obtain a feed-in premium for 25 years. The policy also has implications for hybrid plants, where the feed-in tariff decreases depending on the ratio of energy not produced by a solar energy source.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are:
1. The production of electricity must be from solar thermodynamic plants, including hybrid ones, that are connected to the electricity grid and built in Italy.
2. The plants must be equipped with thermal accumulation systems.
3. The net electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 can obtain a feed-in premium for 25 years.
4. The bonus varies from EUR 0.22 to EUR 0.28 / kWh depending on the level of integration of the plants up to 2012.
5. In case of hybrid plants, the feed-in tariff decreases depending on the ratio between the amount of energy not produced by a solar energy source and the amount produced by a solar energy source.
6. The maximum cumulative power of all solar thermodynamic plants eligible for the incentives corresponds to 1.5 million m2 of cumulative surface.
7. The national objective of total power to be installed by 2016 corresponds to 2 million m2 of cumulative surface.
8. For the 2013-2014 period, bonus values will be reduced by 2% a year.
9. From 2014 onward, a special Ministerial Decree will define further cuts.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy was implemented starting from the Decree of 11 April 2008. The feed-in premium for electricity produced by thermodynamic solar plants commissioned after 18 July 2008 is applicable for 25 years. The bonus values varied from EUR 0.22 to EUR 0.28 / kWh up to 2012. For the 2013-2014 period, the bonus values were reduced by 2% a year. From 2014 onward, further cuts were defined by a special Ministerial Decree. The national objective was to install total power corresponding to 2 million m2 of cumulative surface by 2016.

policy_name: "Energy of the Future" monitoring process Germany (2011)
policy_instrument: Policy support, Institutional creation, Strategic planning
policy_description: At the heart of the monitoring process for the energy transition is the Monitoring Report, which is published on an annual basis. The purpose of this report is to condense the reams of statistical information on energy that have been collected into a smaller, more manageable number of selected indicators. This information provides a fact-based overview of the current status of progress with regard to implementation of the energy reforms. The main source of this data is official energy statistics.
policy_type: Energy service demand reduction and resource efficiency, Energy efficiency, Renewables, Non-energy use, Other low-carbon technologies and fuel switch
who_is_impacted: The policy does not specify particular companies that are impacted. However, it can be inferred that any company involved in the energy sector could be affected. This includes companies involved in energy production, distribution, and consumption, particularly those dealing with renewable energy sources. Additionally, organizations involved in energy-related statistics and research, such as the Federal Network Agency, the Federal Environment Agency, the Federal Motor Transport Authority, the German Institute for Economic Research, Statistik der Kohlenwirtschaft, the Working Group on Renewable Energy Statistics, and the Working Group on Energy Balances, are also involved in the monitoring process of the energy transition.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy include:

1. Continuous monitoring of the energy transition: This involves tracking the progress of the energy transition, assessing the measures that have been implemented, and identifying areas where further efforts are needed.

2. Publication of an annual Monitoring Report: This report condenses the collected statistical information on energy into selected indicators, providing a fact-based overview of the current status of the energy reforms.

3. Publication of a Progress Report every three years: This report provides a broader overview of the energy transition, allowing for deeper analysis over a longer period of time and the identification of trends.

4. Use of energy-related statistics: The monitoring process is based on official energy statistics, with data supplied by various federal agencies and research groups.

5. Compliance with the Energy Statistics Act: This act is the national legal basis for the official energy statistics used in the monitoring process.

6. Involvement of an independent commission of energy experts: This commission provides advice for the drafting process and a scientific opinion on the Monitoring Report.

7. Transmission of the Monitoring Report to the Federal Cabinet, Bundestag, and Bundesrat: The Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy, which leads the monitoring process, is responsible for this transmission.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The policy implementation is ongoing and is monitored on a continuous basis. Each year, a Monitoring Report is published to provide an update on the progress of the energy transition. Additionally, every three years, a Progress Report is published for a deeper analysis over a longer period of time. The first Progress Report was published on 3 December 2014.

who_is_impacted: The policy primarily impacts over 1,000+ electricity providers in the market. It also affects consumers who are looking for electricity tariffs and new customers who can benefit from attractive bonuses offered by many electricity providers.

It encourages the use of digital tools for efficient comparison and selection of the best provider with optimal conditions. policy_description: As part of the "Investment for the Future” programme, ADEME (Agence de l'Environnement et de la Maîtrise de l'Énergie - Environment and Energy Management Agency) supports electromobility through a fund dedicated to local authorities willing to deploy charging infrastructure for Plug-in vehicles. policy_type: Other low-carbon technologies and fuel switch
who_is_impacted: The policy does not specify particular companies that are impacted. However, it could potentially affect any company involved in the production, distribution, or use of Plug-in vehicles, as well as local authorities willing to deploy charging infrastructure for these vehicles.
key_requirements:
The key requirements of this policy are:
1. It is part of the "Investment for the Future" program.
2. It is supported by ADEME.
3. It is dedicated to local authorities willing to deploy charging infrastructure for Plug-in vehicles.
4. The fund has already financed fifteen projects representing more than 5,000 charging points.
5. The policy was renewed on July 17th, 2014 and ended on December 31st, 2015.
timeline_of_policy_implementation: The "Investment for the Future" program began on July 17th, 2014 and ended on December 31st, 2015.
